choices: Equal chest rise and capnography waveform

Fluids & Electrolytes.q: Normal Saline (0.9%) is BEST indicated for:
choices: Severe hyperkalemia with peaked T waves
Fluids & Electrolytes.rationale: NS is isotonic and commonly used for dehydration/hypovolemia per local guidance.

Fluids & Electrolytes.q: Which statement about Lactated Ringers is TRUE?
choices: Preferred in metabolic acidosis, contains Ca and K
Hypertonic and shifts water out of cells
Fluids & Electrolytes.rationale: LR is isotonic and contains Na, K, Ca, Cl; often used in burn/sepsis/acidotic states; use caution in renal failure/hyperkalemia.

Fluids & Electrolytes.q: Hyperkalemia on ECG may present with:
choices: Flattened T waves and narrow QRS
Peaked T waves and wide QRS
ST elevation in inferior leads only
Fluids & Electrolytes.rationale: Classically peaked T waves progressing to QRS widening.

choices: Average arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle
Cardio & Medical.rationale: MAP reflects average perfusion pressure across the cycle.

Cardio & Medical.q: Classic pulmonary embolism field picture includes:
choices: Bradycardia with wheezes resolving with albuterol
Sudden SOB, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, hypoxia
Fever and productive cough over a week
Cardio & Medical.rationale: PE often presents with sudden pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, hypoxia.
Stable angina improves with rest/nitro; unstable persists or occurs at rest.

Regular rhythm, P before each QRS, rate 60–100
Wide QRS with no P waves
Cardiac Rhythms.rationale: NSR: regular, P before each QRS, rate 60–100, normal PR and QRS.

Cardiac Rhythms.q: Monomorphic VT is MOST consistent with:
choices: Wide, regular tachycardia without visible P waves
Cardiac Rhythms.rationale: VT is a wide, regular tachycardia often without discernible P waves.

Trauma Triage.q: Which finding alone meets high-priority transport (physiologic criteria)?
Trauma Triage.rationale: Adult SBP <90 is a high-risk physiologic criterion for trauma activation.

Trauma Triage.q: For suspected tension pneumothorax, the BEST immediate action is:
choices: Needle decompression when indicated by protocol
Trauma Triage.rationale: Needle decompression per protocol addresses life-threatening obstruction to ventilation/circulation.

Trauma Triage.q: In uncontrolled external bleeding, first step is:
Trauma Triage.rationale: Apply direct pressure; escalate to tourniquet if not controlled.

OB/Peds.rationale: Standard scoring at 1 and 5 minutes after birth.

OB/Peds.q: Pediatric ET size (uncuffed) can be estimated by:
OB/Peds.rationale: Common formula: (Age/4) + 4 for uncuffed; (Age/4)+3.5 for cuffed.

OB/Peds.q: JumpSTART triage for apneic child with pulse includes:
choices: Give 2 rescue breaths then re-evaluate breathing
OB/Peds.rationale: Provide 2 rescue breaths; if they start breathing, tag immediate; if not, black.
